I was just showing you. So, first step,
what is Nanite? As most of you probably
know, Nanite is a virtualized geometry
renderer with automatic level of
details. And the way it works is it
renders into a visibility buffer which
is then shaded using compute shaders.
So, if we look at the image on the
right, the way it's rendered is we first
start with that virtualized geometry I
was telling you about. We rasterize this
into a vis buffer and a shading mask.
The vis visibility buffer is made of two
things. It's made of some depth and then
some triangle ID which is used to uni
define which triangle is rendered where.
Um on the shading mask side we end up
with something like this. It's basically
like a buffer of like material ID. So
each pixel is like hey I'm like this
material I'm this other material. What
Unreal then does is it dispatches custom
computed per pixel to shade all of this
into the classic GBuffer to give us our
classic Guffer variable. So stuff like
the color, the normal data or the
roughness.
What we would like to do is hook in
between those two stages to add a custom
material selection pass. What this would
do is it would look over there and
change the shading beans before we shade
them to have per pixel materials.
So to do this, we first need to uh find
where we want to hook. Um the easiest
way to hook into the render pipeline in
Unreal is to use what's called scene
view extensions. Um they look kind of
like this and they allow you to hook
into maybe three places. Um you can hook
before the base pass, after the base
pass, and after all of the all of the
post process passes are run, which might
look fairly limiting, but in practice,
it's been mostly fine for everything we
want to do. You can still do pretty much
everything with these three places. Um
in our case, we want to hook in pre-
pre-render base pass because the vis
buffer is completed before this base
pass. In our case, it be where shading
shading will happen. So we want to right
before it's done. Um so now that we know
where we want to we need to find what we
want to inject at that stage. So we need
to add a custom compute shader. There
are like three main types of shaders in
Unreal. You have the global shader. This
is like a more of a pure HSL math
shader. So you're going to find like the
ambient occision shader. You're going to
find the bloom shader, the SSR shader.
All of these would be like global
shaders. Um you then have material
